item.title: Protecting America’s Waters Story Map
item.description:
Stay Connected

  • Follow us on Twitter
  • Join us on Facebook
  • Subscribe to Water Headlines
  • Learn more about EPA's Office of Water

Since 2009, EPA – in partnership with states, cities, utilities, NGOs, and businesses – has made giant strides to advance clean water protection. Explore the story map below to see where EPA worked to protect waters near you and read about the progress created through historic regulations, new programs, technology advances, and community support that move the country toward cleaner and more reliable water.

Explore Protecting America’s Waters Story Map

Read text-only version of the Protecting America’s Waters Story Map

Read more about EPA's major water accomplishments:
Huffington Post: "Water Challenges are Actually Opportunities" by EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy, 12/8/2016

EPA Water Progress Infographic
item.dc:creator: npetricc

item.title: The National Aquatic Resource Surveys (NARS)
item.description:
• Basic Description
  • Link to Data
  • Other Resources

The National Aquatic Resource Surveys (NARS) are statistical surveys designed to assess the status of and changes in quality of the nation’s coastal waters, lakes and reservoirs, rivers and streams, and wetlands. Using sample sites selected at random, these surveys provide a snapshot of the overall condition of the nation’s water.

  • Data from the National Aquatic Resource Surveys

More information about NARS:

  • Background of the NARS
  • NARS Data FAQs
  • Journal Articles Applying NARS Data
item.dc:creator: apage01

item.title: Compliance Monitoring Data Portal
item.description:
The Compliance Monitoring Data Portal (CMDP) will enable drinking water utilities and laboratories to report data electronically to primacy agencies with fewer errors and in a more efficient manner.

  • Basic Information
  • Get Data Tool
  • Learn More

The CMDP will increase data accuracy and completeness and once fully implemented, can potentially decrease the overall reporting burden for primacy agencies hundreds of thousands of hours.

  • Learn more basic information about CMDP.
  • Review the Drinking Water Data and Reports

Primacy agencies that are interested in learning more about CMDP can visit the CMDP Help Center Exit
item.dc:creator: apage01

item.title: Monthly Conference Calls
item.description:
The EPA STORET Team hosts conference calls about once a month to allow STORET/ WQX users to hear about developments with the STORET/ WQX System and express their comments/questions directly to the STORET staff. Minutes from previous calls are posted below.

  • STORET User Call Minutes 10/27/2016 (PDF)(2 pp, 405 K)
  • STORET User Call Minutes 9/22/2016 (PDF)(2 pp, 106 K)
  • STORET User Call minutes 5/26/2016 (PDF)(2 pp, 98 K)
  • STORET User Call Minutes 4/28/2016 (PDF)(2 pp, 81 K)
  • STORET User Call Minutes 1/28/2016 (PDF)(2 pp, 112 K)
item.dc:creator: xasuarez

item.title: HAWQSbetaflyer
item.description:
HAWQS is a web-based interactive water quantity and quality modeling system that provides users with interactive web interfaces and maps; pre-loaded input data; outputs that include tables, charts, graphs and raw output data; and a user guide.

  • hawqsbetaflyer (PDF)(2 pp, 2 MB)
item.dc:creator: xasuarez

item.title: Water Quality Portal Data Discovery Tool
item.description:
What are the capabilities of the tool?

The Water Quality Portal (WQP) Data Discovery tool is a desktop application that provides an easy to use interface allowing users to search, summarize, QC and display data from the WQP.

What data is available?

The Data Discovery Tool, developed by the EPA and powered by the Water Quality Portal Exit services, allows you to access publicly available water-quality data from the EPA Storage and Retrieval Data Warehouse (STORET), USGS National Water Information System (NWIS), and USDA ARS Sustaining the Earth's Watersheds, Agricultural Research Data System (STEWARDS).

How can I get the tool and get started using it?

The tool uses open source R, a statistical programming language and several add-on packages, to visualize the data selected from the portal and to assist users in data analysis.  You must have at least version 3.2.1 of R on your computer to run the tool, which can be downloaded from the Comprehensive R Archive Network Exit.  After R is installed, download the Water Quality Portal Data Discovery Tool(197 MB) , unzip the file to your local file directory and reference the Quick Start Guide to get started using the tool.
item.dc:creator: xapassam
